widgets_values:
1
00:00:01,999 --> 00:00:07,679
Hello there and welcome to a new Digital Foundry analysis taking a look at I guess what is our

2
00:00:07,679 --> 00:00:15,500
first experience of FSR Redstone a machine learning based ray regeneration feature has been added to

3
00:00:15,500 --> 00:00:22,339
Call of Duty Black Ops 7 and obviously there's going to be comparisons here with what Nvidia

4
00:00:22,339 --> 00:00:29,100
is doing with dlss but as you shall discover there's a few wrinkles along the way the man

5
00:00:29,100 --> 00:00:34,719
who has actually done the heavy lifting here i.e all the work is Alex Batalia hello yes there rich

6
00:00:34,719 --> 00:00:39,200
I've spent the last couple of days looking at this technology after it launched at the end of last

7
00:00:39,200 --> 00:00:45,640
week and I've got a lot to say yes and not all of it is good but I think first of all we need to

8
00:00:45,640 --> 00:00:50,560
talk about the the way that ray regeneration has been implemented into Black Ops 7 because

9
00:00:50,560 --> 00:00:58,640
I'm looking at your notes here and my summary of those notes would be one word weird yeah it's

10
00:00:59,100 --> 00:01:05,819
strange one adding into Black Ops 7 and having it only apply to the multiplayer zombie portion of

11
00:01:05,819 --> 00:01:10,019
the game that that's a little bit weird in general like you it's only in one part of the game and not

12
00:01:10,019 --> 00:01:16,099
in the other yeah but as for testing purposes and also just general like user experience it's a

13
00:01:16,099 --> 00:01:21,920
little bit weird having a multiplayer title in the multiplayer component only for you know for

14
00:01:21,920 --> 00:01:27,340
reviewers like us it's hard to actually get the recordings I for my all this footage here I deliver

15
00:01:34,959 --> 00:01:59,079
this caught up because there are multiple forms ofremove which have their own

16
00:01:59,099 --> 00:02:05,840
reflections in reflections in them. But it's, you know, ray reconstruction from the NVIDIA side,

17
00:02:06,040 --> 00:02:12,319
or things like NRD, or any of the other larger scale denoisers also cover other aspects of

18
00:02:12,319 --> 00:02:17,599
ray tracing denoising, including like direct shadows, direct lighting, indirect diffuse

19
00:02:17,599 --> 00:02:25,479
lighting. And with this implementation of ray regeneration here, in Black Ops 7, we're only

20
00:02:25,479 --> 00:02:28,879
seeing reflections. So we're not actually getting a full picture.

21
00:02:29,680 --> 00:02:35,240
Right. Okay. And on top of that, there's other stuff as well, for example, and I think that

22
00:02:35,240 --> 00:02:42,340
really sticks out to me here. On the same settings, the game can present differently on NVIDIA and AMD

23
00:02:43,020 --> 00:02:43,639
GPUs, right?

24
00:02:43,879 --> 00:02:49,620
I don't know what this is about. I've reinstalled drivers, both for AMD and NVIDIA here, because I

25
00:02:49,620 --> 00:02:53,819
don't know what I'm looking at necessarily. But just like, look at this scene here in the training

26
00:02:53,819 --> 00:02:54,099
map.

27
00:02:55,020 --> 00:02:55,460
Okay.

28
00:02:55,460 --> 00:02:59,639
I flip back and forth between them, and you'll see like, hey, wait, why is this like one image

29
00:02:59,639 --> 00:03:05,159
darker? Why is one lighter? And it has to do with like shadows, as well as some of the post-processing

30
00:03:05,159 --> 00:03:09,379
reproduction. And if you like zoom in a corner, you'll see that the distance at which shadows

31
00:03:09,379 --> 00:03:13,680
renders at the same settings are actually different. And I don't know what's causing that.

32
00:03:13,740 --> 00:03:19,620
Then, like in another scene here, you can see that the way shadows are rendered entirely is

33
00:03:19,620 --> 00:03:25,439
different. They have like, they're more opaque in some settings.

34
00:03:25,460 --> 00:03:31,199
So, you can see that the light is more intense on the AMD side, and they're darker on the NVIDIA side.

35
00:03:31,740 --> 00:03:37,840
I don't know why this is the case, but we're not seeing the same one-to-one visuals here when I look at

36
00:03:37,840 --> 00:03:45,120
this game, as well as the ray tracing itself is different between the vendors. In this scene here, from

37
00:03:45,120 --> 00:03:51,479
that training map, you'll see that there are reflections of lights on the floor that just aren't there on

38
00:03:51,479 --> 00:03:52,419
the AMD side.

39
00:03:52,419 --> 00:04:02,020
And another similar area of that map, once again, more missing lights on the AMD side, as well as the decals on the wall showing

40
00:04:02,020 --> 00:04:05,139
like lettering and whatnot for this cool little sci-fi area.

41
00:04:05,240 --> 00:04:08,039
Yeah, they're missing there too on the AMD side.

42
00:04:08,259 --> 00:04:13,199
So, we're not getting really one-to-one comparisons here as much as I would like.

43
00:04:13,259 --> 00:04:20,879
So, sometimes you'll see maybe differences in the comparisons I show, and it could be chalked up to differences in, or just buggy visuals in general.

44
00:04:21,000 --> 00:04:21,980
Like, I just don't know.

45
00:04:22,120 --> 00:04:22,160
Right.

46
00:04:22,420 --> 00:04:22,980
Yeah.

47
00:04:23,319 --> 00:04:23,800
Okay.

48
00:04:23,920 --> 00:04:24,079
Yeah.

49
00:04:24,139 --> 00:04:29,740
And there's other things as well, because, well, obviously, when you're looking at that kind of evidence, it kind of suggests that doing like-for-like

50
00:04:29,740 --> 00:04:35,500
benchmarks between NVIDIA and AMD is probably not a good idea because ultimately they're not rendering the same things.

51
00:04:35,779 --> 00:04:46,939
But let's talk more specifically about FSR ray regeneration, because, you know, going into this, it would be, well, you'd kind of think that ray

52
00:04:46,939 --> 00:04:52,120
regeneration is essentially AMD's answer to DLSS ray reconstruction, right?

53
00:04:53,860 --> 00:04:57,160
However, it's not quite that cut and dried, is it?

54
00:04:57,620 --> 00:04:58,019
No.

55
00:04:58,139 --> 00:05:04,759
I think here, in a little way, it's a little bit like FSR 1.0 versus DLSS 2.0.

56
00:05:04,860 --> 00:05:06,300
And I don't mean to say that as like a negative way.

57
00:05:06,399 --> 00:05:08,379
Rather, we're kind of looking at two different approaches.

58
00:05:08,780 --> 00:05:18,439
I'm actually not sure if this is the nth degree goal of what AMD actually wants Redstone's ray regeneration tech to be.

59
00:05:19,180 --> 00:05:22,040
And I think the way you can see that is if you just look in the menu.

60
00:05:22,060 --> 00:05:22,100
Yeah.

61
00:05:23,019 --> 00:05:27,399
With ray regeneration on, it doesn't require FSR 4.

62
00:05:27,899 --> 00:05:30,240
It's not, it doesn't require it at all.

63
00:05:30,279 --> 00:05:31,399
You can turn on FSR 3.

64
00:05:31,519 --> 00:05:32,879
You can turn on XCSS.

65
00:05:33,220 --> 00:05:35,600
You can turn on the game's TAA, I guess.

66
00:05:35,740 --> 00:05:37,240
I only tried it with FSR 3.

67
00:05:37,939 --> 00:05:44,079
And as you can see here, the two different, there's differences in image quality between these two versions.

68
00:05:44,180 --> 00:05:44,519
Right.

69
00:05:44,639 --> 00:05:48,079
Ray regeneration with FSR 3, ray regeneration with FSR 4.

70
00:05:48,360 --> 00:05:51,040
And this is actually very different than what NVIDIA does.

71
00:05:51,040 --> 00:06:03,879
Where when you turn on ray reconstruction, it turns on an entirely different and much heavier algorithm that combines the upscaling step with the denoising step.

72
00:06:04,139 --> 00:06:07,360
And that has a number of advantages for performance as well as visuals.

73
00:06:07,759 --> 00:06:19,579
And you can kind of see what I mean by that when you compare ray reconstruction on the NVIDIA side versus AMD for things that are highly mirror-like.

74
00:06:19,579 --> 00:06:20,519
Right.

75
00:06:20,800 --> 00:06:22,459
Like here on this puddle on the ground.

76
00:06:22,540 --> 00:06:24,899
I want you to focus on like this one edge here that I've highlighted.

77
00:06:25,560 --> 00:06:33,180
On the ray regeneration side, you can see like the internal 1080p resolution here from 4K performance mode FSR 4 here.

78
00:06:33,480 --> 00:06:39,040
Versus on the NVIDIA side, it's more like a straight anti-aliased 4K edge.

79
00:06:39,480 --> 00:06:42,660
And that has some repercussions.

80
00:06:42,680 --> 00:06:49,560
It's a lot more like older denoising tech visually than it is like something that we expected from the NVIDIA side.

82
00:06:49,579 --> 00:06:51,480
So, it's a lot more like a ray reconstruction competitor.

83
00:06:52,019 --> 00:06:52,360
Okay.

84
00:06:52,399 --> 00:07:03,620
So, just to sort of boil it down to a more sort of simple take, it's like ray reconstruction is not just a denoiser but also an upscaler for ray traced effects, right?

85
00:07:03,720 --> 00:07:04,079
Yes.

86
00:07:04,100 --> 00:07:10,139
Because obviously, if you don't have that upscaling effect, you've got like, you know, everything else is upscaled.

87
00:07:10,139 --> 00:07:16,379
But the reflections or whatever is being reconstructed with ray reconstruction would still be at a lower resolution.

88
00:07:16,779 --> 00:07:19,399
So, ray reconstruction is also upscaling.

89
00:07:19,579 --> 00:07:32,300
But what we're seeing here with FSR 4 ray regeneration, it doesn't seem to be that upscaling step, which kind of explains why it seems to be operating also as an option with FSR 3 or TAA or XESS, right?

90
00:07:32,560 --> 00:07:32,800
Yeah.

91
00:07:32,959 --> 00:07:47,819
And a really good example that you can find, and I saw Daniel Owen pointed this out as well too, and so did Computerbase, is that the reflections on water look very different between ray reconstruction at the same resolution as ray regeneration.

92
00:07:47,920 --> 00:07:49,560
And like you can see in this example here.

93
00:07:49,560 --> 00:07:52,540
It just like, they look a lot softer and lower res.

94
00:07:52,759 --> 00:07:59,019
And I saw some speculation online like, oh, is one representing water more realistically than the other?

95
00:07:59,139 --> 00:08:00,120
And the answer is no.

96
00:08:00,319 --> 00:08:07,000
Ray regeneration doesn't appear to be doing the upscaling of the ray tracing effect like ray reconstruction does.

97
00:08:07,220 --> 00:08:17,540
You can see that difference if you turn up ray regeneration's internal resolution to native, for example, 4K FSR 4 native resolution, and you put them all side by side.

98
00:08:17,540 --> 00:08:26,379
Left 4K performance mode FSR 4, in the middle 4K FSR 4 native, and then ray reconstruction at internal 1080p there.

99
00:08:26,620 --> 00:08:36,820
And you'll see that the 4K native version of ray regeneration looks a lot closer in sharpness, much like DLSS 4 ray reconstruction.

100
00:08:37,480 --> 00:08:47,440
And I think that's what we're seeing here is this, it's actually doing a lot of the work when the output is still like at the internal resolution that it's actually rendering.

101
00:08:47,440 --> 00:08:48,340
At 1080p.

102
00:08:48,580 --> 00:08:57,059
So when I'm preparing here, it almost feels a little unfair because I don't think these technologies are actually doing the same thing, which is really strange.

103
00:08:57,460 --> 00:08:57,940
Okay.

104
00:08:58,019 --> 00:09:04,840
So I'm kind of reminded of the debut of FSR 3 frame generation here, where we had like what you might call a proof of concept.

105
00:09:04,919 --> 00:09:05,419
It worked.

106
00:09:05,440 --> 00:09:08,379
It was integrated into a couple of games in that case.

107
00:09:08,539 --> 00:09:10,720
But it wasn't the final thing, right?

108
00:09:10,779 --> 00:09:14,019
It wasn't the technology that we have today.

109
00:09:14,179 --> 00:09:15,580
It was a preview of sorts even.

110
00:09:16,159 --> 00:09:17,299
With certain limitations.

111
00:09:17,299 --> 00:09:17,419
Right.

112
00:09:17,440 --> 00:09:17,759
With certain conditions.

113
00:09:17,759 --> 00:09:23,360
Now, we don't actually know whether that's the case here because we haven't really had a huge amount of messaging from AMD.

114
00:09:23,860 --> 00:09:27,399
But it does kind of feel like a work in progress rendition, right?

115
00:09:27,539 --> 00:09:27,960
Yeah.

116
00:09:28,259 --> 00:09:32,919
There's a couple things that give me that feeling from the visual feature set.

117
00:09:33,159 --> 00:09:43,159
Now, one thing that reflections do on semi-glossy surfaces or rougher reflections, as you call them, is that when you look at the bottom of the reflection where it meets the object, it's very sharp.

118
00:09:43,259 --> 00:09:45,679
And then it starts to get more diffuse as you look along.

119
00:09:45,679 --> 00:09:50,340
The edge of the reflection as it goes away from the object that it's reflecting.

120
00:09:51,080 --> 00:09:54,259
And that's something that seems to be missing in ray regeneration.

121
00:09:54,600 --> 00:09:59,320
And that's a typical feature of reflections that is reconstructed in the denoising step.

122
00:09:59,600 --> 00:10:05,440
That's like there's so much noise that you have to kind of reconstruct that effect of reflections.

123
00:10:05,679 --> 00:10:10,120
And that's missing in ray regen in a number of areas that I've looked in.

124
00:10:10,220 --> 00:10:13,840
Like, for example, here on the floor.

125
00:10:13,980 --> 00:10:15,659
You can see that on the right.

126
00:10:15,659 --> 00:10:18,000
On the ray reconstruction side, it starts off really sharp.

127
00:10:18,120 --> 00:10:21,360
And then it gets tapered at the end and more diffuse.

128
00:10:21,620 --> 00:10:26,639
Whereas on the ray regeneration side, it stays sharp the entire length of the reflection.

129
00:10:27,019 --> 00:10:41,700
And the same goes in the other direction where if a surface is very, has a very rough reflection on the AMD ray regeneration side, it's entirely rough no matter how close it is to the object like we see here.

130
00:10:42,100 --> 00:10:43,340
Next to this trash can.

131
00:10:43,559 --> 00:10:43,899
Woohoo.

132
00:10:43,899 --> 00:10:44,639
Trash can.

133
00:10:45,700 --> 00:10:47,399
And I love DF.

134
00:10:47,460 --> 00:10:49,379
We talk about ray traced toilets and trash cans.

135
00:10:49,460 --> 00:10:50,240
This is our job.

136
00:10:50,639 --> 00:11:00,519
But, yeah, you look here and you can see that it's like entirely blurry, the entire length of the reflection versus on the ray reconstruction side where it has that contact hardening effect that you expect.

137
00:11:01,460 --> 00:11:13,220
So missing stuff like that in combination with the fact that it doesn't appear to be a combination upscaler denoiser makes me think this is not a complete product.

138
00:11:13,379 --> 00:11:13,879
Yeah.

139
00:11:13,879 --> 00:11:16,279
Did you want to talk a bit about quality and performance here?

140
00:11:16,379 --> 00:11:19,659
Because there's some points we need to go through there, right?

141
00:11:19,879 --> 00:11:20,519
Yeah, sure.

142
00:11:20,679 --> 00:11:25,940
So there's some stuff that I think will change over time with this.

143
00:11:26,039 --> 00:11:36,600
One thing that I want to point out that it does really well at the moment is moving objects and reflections as well as animated billboards and reflections.

144
00:11:36,980 --> 00:11:41,259
This training level has a number of sci-fi billboards in them.

145
00:11:41,399 --> 00:11:43,860
And there's some very, like, either.

147
00:11:43,860 --> 00:11:48,360
Water reflections on the ground or just very reflective surfaces like metal floors.

148
00:11:48,519 --> 00:11:51,720
And in them you can see the reflections of these billboards in them.

149
00:11:52,019 --> 00:11:54,539
On the ray reconstruction side, they're much higher res looking.

150
00:11:55,419 --> 00:11:57,080
That's because I think that's the way it is.

151
00:11:57,159 --> 00:12:07,159
But you'll notice that the detail in the reflection will have ghosty areas where the detail resolves over multiple frames incorrectly.

152
00:12:07,600 --> 00:12:13,200
Whereas on the ray regeneration side, in spite of it being lower res, it's holding it at least.

153
00:12:13,200 --> 00:12:14,919
Without the ghosting.

154
00:12:14,940 --> 00:12:18,139
And that looks quite a bit better, I would say, for that aspect.

155
00:12:18,320 --> 00:12:19,240
And it does that really well.

156
00:12:19,480 --> 00:12:26,080
Another thing that it does quite a bit better is some moving objects and reflections on, like, more glossy surfaces.

157
00:12:26,679 --> 00:12:28,220
You can see, like, here.

158
00:12:28,899 --> 00:12:32,000
There's this weird rotating dial in the middle of the map.

159
00:12:32,139 --> 00:12:43,179
And one of those rotating features of it, when you look at its reflection on the ground, you'll see in the ray regeneration side versus ray reconstruction that it holds its silhouette back.

160
00:12:43,179 --> 00:12:45,899
And it doesn't blur it or ghost it away a bit.

161
00:12:46,059 --> 00:12:48,120
And that's something that it does really, really well.

162
00:12:48,259 --> 00:12:52,320
So it's holding, it's handling motion quite a bit well for those things.

163
00:12:53,320 --> 00:12:56,519
But at the same time, some other motion aspects are not as good.

164
00:12:56,620 --> 00:12:57,740
For example, disocclusion.

165
00:12:57,919 --> 00:13:13,159
Like, you can see that on the water in the training map where when you move your gun out of the way, on the ray regeneration side, it shows, like, the silhouette of the gun in, like, a blurry detail form there for quite a number of frames after the gun's moved away.

166
00:13:13,159 --> 00:13:16,720
So it does movement pretty okay.

167
00:13:16,919 --> 00:13:21,500
But disocclusion seems to be very work in progress at the moment, to say the least.

168
00:13:21,620 --> 00:13:21,720
Okay.

169
00:13:23,360 --> 00:13:25,100
Performance, frame rates.

170
00:13:25,379 --> 00:13:28,700
There's obviously a computational hit to ray regeneration, right?

171
00:13:29,460 --> 00:13:29,980
Yeah.

172
00:13:30,220 --> 00:13:31,340
And also, no.

173
00:13:31,559 --> 00:13:33,620
And I'm not the only one who's measured this.

174
00:13:33,700 --> 00:13:36,519
I looked at computer-based to double-check to see I wasn't going crazy.

175
00:13:37,220 --> 00:13:43,139
But if you look at the game's benchmark and turn off ray regeneration and the game's base detail form, you'll see that it's not that bad.

176
00:13:43,139 --> 00:13:43,419
It's just that it's not as good as the game's base denoiser.

177
00:13:43,799 --> 00:13:52,700
Like, you compare the two in terms of performance, you'll see that ray regeneration costs more or less the exact same as the game's base denoiser.

178
00:13:53,139 --> 00:13:57,539
It's about one frame per second difference between these two benchmark runs.

179
00:13:57,600 --> 00:13:59,399
And I ran it, like, three or four times.

180
00:13:59,559 --> 00:14:03,679
So the average cost is the same as the game's base denoiser more or less.

181
00:14:04,980 --> 00:14:13,080
And the weird thing, too, is I also checked out whether or not turning on FSR4 with ray regeneration would have a different performance.

183
00:14:13,120 --> 00:14:18,120
And I found that it ran more or less the same, too.

184
00:14:18,559 --> 00:14:19,940
Which is interesting.

185
00:14:20,139 --> 00:14:27,720
I guess that points to some other bottlenecking occurring in the architecture that is keeping the performance much the same.

186
00:14:27,840 --> 00:14:37,340
But once again, computer-based also found at the resolutions they tested that the performance between the denoiser and ray regeneration was more or less the exact same.

187
00:14:37,480 --> 00:14:38,360
So I'm not alone.

188
00:14:38,480 --> 00:14:38,720
Interesting.

189
00:14:39,000 --> 00:14:39,559
Yeah.

190
00:14:39,600 --> 00:14:43,100
Well, you would kind of hope that machine learning-based denoiser would be the same as the game's base denoiser.

193
00:14:43,100 --> 00:14:48,759
But I think that the game's base denoiser would be, like, you know, as performant as the basic one that's of a lower quality, right?

194
00:14:48,879 --> 00:14:49,200
Yeah.

195
00:14:49,919 --> 00:14:52,519
In that case, that is a job well done.

196
00:14:52,600 --> 00:15:06,620
And you'd want to keep them within the same amount so that you at least when the quality improves over time with, like, different network weights and whatnot and just better training, that you get a much better image for this relatively similar cost.

197
00:15:06,799 --> 00:15:13,080
Which is the nth-degree goal for this project, I assume, after they get past this initial almost beta-looking phase of it.

198
00:15:13,080 --> 00:15:13,940
Okay.

199
00:15:14,059 --> 00:15:14,440
Right.

200
00:15:14,580 --> 00:15:14,879
Fair enough.

201
00:15:14,980 --> 00:15:16,799
Any final thoughts before we wrap up?

202
00:15:17,200 --> 00:15:17,639
Yeah.

203
00:15:17,720 --> 00:15:23,340
I think this is altogether a very strange way to demo this exciting new technology.

204
00:15:24,340 --> 00:15:28,019
It's going to be part of the next PlayStation, probably part of the next Xbox.

205
00:15:28,460 --> 00:15:34,399
And the way it's kind of pushed out on PC right now seems like it was pushed out when it wasn't ready yet.

206
00:15:34,679 --> 00:15:41,480
And perhaps before even internally the engineering team might have said, oh, yeah, it's, like, feature complete.

207
00:15:42,000 --> 00:15:43,059
Because a lot of the stuff is already there.

208
00:15:43,080 --> 00:15:48,159
And a lot of the stuff here doesn't seem like it's feature complete, like the lack of contact hardening and whatnot.

209
00:15:49,099 --> 00:16:01,100
Also being pushed as a part of, like, multiplayer-only Call of Duty on top of, like, the visual bugs in the generic Call of Duty graphics between vendors makes me think that this entire thing is a bit questionable.

210
00:16:01,340 --> 00:16:08,519
Like, I'm not sure if the things I'm seeing are bugs or just the state of the product as it is right now.

211
00:16:08,639 --> 00:16:11,019
So that's always not a good thing.

212
00:16:11,019 --> 00:16:20,820
I also maybe would have loved a little bit more internal information from an AMD and, like, a blog post about how it works and what to expect of the technology.

213
00:16:21,059 --> 00:16:26,720
But at the moment, it's just mainly what you see visually on screen and then doing the comparisons by yourself.

214
00:16:26,980 --> 00:16:28,480
So, yeah.

215
00:16:28,820 --> 00:16:31,000
General puzzlement, really, isn't it?

216
00:16:31,700 --> 00:16:32,159
Yeah.

217
00:16:32,939 --> 00:16:37,559
I didn't know what to make of it when it launched because I only heard about it via a tweet.

218
00:16:37,759 --> 00:16:38,940
And I was like, what?

219
00:16:39,179 --> 00:16:39,379
What?

220
00:16:39,379 --> 00:16:44,940
This game has ray tracing and it has the first part of FSR Redstone?

221
00:16:45,159 --> 00:16:47,000
And lo and behold, it did.

222
00:16:47,120 --> 00:16:49,919
But I didn't really know about that until, like, quite late.

223
00:16:50,399 --> 00:16:51,639
So that's the way it is.

224
00:16:52,000 --> 00:16:53,679
It's very, very strange.

225
00:16:53,840 --> 00:16:55,659
It's a bit of a bizarre product debut.

226
00:16:55,840 --> 00:16:57,139
But there it is.

227
00:16:57,200 --> 00:17:01,879
And I guess we're not going to be doing huge, more in-depth testing on this because, well, two reasons.

228
00:17:02,000 --> 00:17:04,920
First of all, it doesn't seem to be the final product.

229
00:17:05,119 --> 00:17:07,380
And secondly, we can't, basically.

230
00:17:08,720 --> 00:17:09,160
No.

231
00:17:09,160 --> 00:17:10,779
There's a lot of bizarre stuff happening here.

232
00:17:10,900 --> 00:17:14,160
The fact that you can't use it in the campaign is just kind of baffling.

233
00:17:14,240 --> 00:17:16,460
I'm wondering if it's an art issue or something like that.

234
00:17:18,339 --> 00:17:21,039
But, yeah, just general strangeness.

235
00:17:21,140 --> 00:17:31,819
But I guess we're just going to have to wait and see what further FSR Redstone disclosures will happen and new game integrations to actually get a better feel for what AMD is trying to achieve here.

236
00:17:32,500 --> 00:17:32,940
Yeah.

237
00:17:33,099 --> 00:17:38,440
I think if it comes to more games as well as coming to, like, more path tracing titles,

238
00:17:38,440 --> 00:17:44,279
where we can see more of its performance for other aspects of image lighting, then we'll have a better understanding of it.

239
00:17:44,420 --> 00:17:51,960
And just like, you know, DLSS Ray Reconstruction, when the original 3.5 version came out, we talked about how it had, like, this smudgy ghosting look.

240
00:17:52,140 --> 00:17:56,599
That improved over time with other versions as well as the change over to Transformer model.

241
00:17:56,900 --> 00:18:01,039
I think we're going to see a very similar trajectory with Ray Regeneration when the time comes.

242
00:18:01,599 --> 00:18:02,000
Okay.

243
00:18:02,079 --> 00:18:02,519
Good stuff.

244
00:18:02,640 --> 00:18:03,759
Well, that's all we've got for this one.

245
00:18:03,920 --> 00:18:08,339
But if you enjoyed the content, please do like, subscribe, share, ring bells for notifications for you.

246
00:18:08,339 --> 00:18:17,440
And if you want to see more of the new alleged potential algorithmic boosts for us, but really it's all about the DF Supporter Program, join us, patreon.com slash digitalfoundry.

247
00:18:17,539 --> 00:18:21,000
And do check out our brand new website at digitalfoundry.net.

248
00:18:21,119 --> 00:18:23,099
But that's all from us on this one.

249
00:18:23,180 --> 00:18:25,740
Thanks for watching and supporting Digital Foundry.
